metadata.sermon_title: The Little Church in the Wilderness—1 Kings 17
metadata.sermon_start_end: On the eastern shore of Maryland there is an Episcopal church that has a full service of Morning Prayer each weekday. When I drive down to visit my mother in Virginia, I always stop there. They used to have a decent number of people in attendance, but last week [...] There is no one who does not play a part, and the mighty works of God continue apace, and each person may at any time be called out of his or her place to give assistance to God’s great enterprise, and the angels rejoice to see the little churches in the wilderness — because he watching over Israel slumbers not nor sleeps. Praised be the living God! AMEN.
metadata.notes: The sermon makes extensive use of a 19th-century source (Krummacher) as a secondary interpretive lens.

phase_1_concrete_experience.analysis: The sermon begins with a strong concrete experience by describing a specific visit to a church in Maryland. It grounds the biblical narrative in the physical reality of 'two women of a certain age' and later uses vivid imagery to describe Elijah as an 'action figure.' However, the experience of the widow herself is mediated through a 19th-century commentary rather than direct narrative immersion, which slightly distances the hearer from her immediate struggle.
quotes: When I drive down to visit my mother in Virginia, I always stop there... last week there were only two — two women 'of a certain age.'
He delivers more fireworks than all the other prophets put together. Boys today like 'action figures' — well, Elijah is one of the greatest action figures of all.
strengths: Effective use of a personal 'hook' that connects to the sermon's main theme.
Vivid characterization of Elijah that creates immediate mental images.
improvement_points: The widow's experience is described more than it is felt; more sensory detail regarding the famine would deepen the empathy.
The transition from the Maryland church to the biblical text is somewhat abrupt.
phase_1_concrete_experience.homiletical_manifestations: Hook in introduction; use of contemporary analogies (CEO, Secretary of War, Tour de France) to make characters recognizable.

phase_2_reflective_observation.analysis: This is a strong phase in the sermon. The preacher pauses to analyze the 'why' behind Elijah's journey, specifically the necessity of humility. There is a sophisticated cultural and ecclesiastical critique of the 'mainline' vs. 'evangelical' divide, asking why certain churches are failing. It moves beyond the story to observe the underlying spiritual patterns of power and vulnerability.
quotes: This is the Lord’s hard way of teaching us our place before him. Beware of the doctor who has never been sick...
Why are the mainline churches having so much trouble? ... very rarely do I hear about a living God.
strengths: Deep reflection on the nature of ego and divine service.
Insightful analysis of the contemporary American religious landscape.
improvement_points: The reflection on the 'mainline' church condition is lengthy and could risk losing the connection to the specific widow narrative.
The use of Krummacher as a reflective partner is effective but occasionally feels like a lecture on homiletical history.
phase_2_reflective_observation.homiletical_manifestations: Existential questions about the 'living God'; cultural critique of American Christianity; psychological analysis of Elijah's ego.

phase_3_abstract_conceptualization.analysis: The theological core is the concept of the 'Living God' (Theos) versus human-centered activity. The sermon formulates a clear 'big idea': the church exists only in its standing before God. While the exegesis is solid, it relies heavily on Krummacher’s 19th-century framework rather than developing a fresh systematic theological argument for the 21st century.
quotes: As the Lord the God of Israel lives, before whom I stand. ... The living God of Elijah does not seem to be in view.
Preaching that is grounded in theos, the living God, and in the living Word of such a God.
strengths: Clear articulation of the 'Living God' as the central theological pivot.
Strong connection between the Old Testament narrative and New Testament Christology.
improvement_points: The theological 'big idea' is somewhat repetitive in the latter half.
Could benefit from more direct engagement with the Hebrew text's nuances rather than relying on Krummacher's interpretation.
phase_3_abstract_conceptualization.homiletical_manifestations: Theological deepening of the phrase 'before whom I stand'; dogmatic distinction between humanism and theism.

phase_4_active_experimentation.analysis: This is the weakest phase. While the sermon calls the congregation to be a 'little church in the wilderness' and to 'tell truth to power,' these remain largely abstract or corporate calls. There are few concrete, individual action steps for the hearer to implement on Monday morning. The application is more about the 'identity' of the church than the 'action' of the believer.
quotes: This congregation... may very well find itself called out to stand before kings, so to speak, to tell truth to power.
The ministry that goes on without fanfare — the serving of meals, the reading of the daily office, the visiting of the sick.
strengths: Identifies the daily office and visiting the sick as valid forms of 'experimentation.'
Encourages a specific corporate identity for a 'prosperous' church.
improvement_points: The call to 'tell truth to power' is metaphorical ('so to speak') and lacks a specific contemporary target or method.
Needs more 'how-to' for the individual hearer to transition from 'standing before God' to acting in the world.
phase_4_active_experimentation.homiletical_manifestations: Ethical call to sacrifice and service; invitation to see daily tasks as divine participation.

declarative_assimilating.preacher_role: The preacher acts as a Philosopher/Theologian, diagnosing the state of the American church.
declarative_assimilating.core_question_answered: What is the truth about why churches are declining? (Loss of the 'Living God').
declarative_assimilating.analysis: The sermon uses a deductive logic in its second half, moving from the general state of US Christianity to the specific calling of this congregation.
quotes: The problem is that we start thinking that this human activity is what drives the engine of the church.
strengths: Logical categorization of church types.
Clear thesis.
improvement_points: Could be more concise in the sociological analysis.

pragmatic_converging.preacher_role: The preacher briefly acts as a Guide, pointing toward social justice and tradition.
pragmatic_converging.core_question_answered: How does a church survive the 'wilderness'? (By combining theology and justice).
pragmatic_converging.analysis: Pragmatism is limited to broad institutional advice rather than personal coaching.
quotes: Because you combine two things... biblical and theological preaching... and a strong tradition of involvement in social justice.
strengths: Affirms existing strengths of the congregation.
improvement_points: Lacks 'step-by-step' guidance for the 'how' of this combination.

narrative_accommodating.preacher_role: The preacher is a Storyteller, recounting the Maryland visit and the Zarephath story.
narrative_accommodating.core_question_answered: What happens when a prophet meets a widow?
narrative_accommodating.analysis: The narrative is strong but interrupted by long stretches of commentary and analysis.
quotes: I told them that I was going to put them into my Sunday sermon. In due course you will see what I mean.
strengths: Engaging opening story.
Good use of dramatic tension in the Elijah description.
improvement_points: The narrative of the widow's son being raised is rushed at the end.

visionary_diverging.preacher_role: The preacher acts as a Poet, using the 'Little Church in the Wilderness' metaphor.
visionary_diverging.core_question_answered: Why is this important? (Because we stand before the Living God).
visionary_diverging.analysis: The sermon uses powerful metaphors (Trojan horse, action figures, wadi, wilderness) to awaken longing.
quotes: The angels of God have rejoiced... over this little church in the wilderness!
strengths: Strong central metaphor.
Inspiring concluding vision.
improvement_points: The 'Trojan horse' metaphor is introduced but not fully resolved.

descriptive_empirical.priestly_listening: The preacher has clearly observed the 'prosperous' context of the church and the 'emptiness' of mainline liturgy.
descriptive_empirical.analysis: Excellent identification of the 'what': a religious country where the church is losing its soul.
quotes: I’ve been listening to sermons... for nine years... and very rarely do I hear about a living God.
strengths: Honest assessment of the congregation's status.
Specific observation of the Maryland church.
improvement_points: Could include more specific 'needs' of the university town context.

interpretive.wisdom_of_sage: Uses sociological categories to interpret the decline of mainline denominations.
interpretive.analysis: Explains 'why' by pointing to a lack of theological grounding in social justice movements.
quotes: These commitments have waned in many cases because of a lack of theological grounding.
strengths: Balanced critique of both right and left.
Wise use of historical perspective.
improvement_points: The psychological interpretation of Elijah's ego could be more grounded in the text.

normative.prophetic_discernment: The sermon is strongly normative, calling the church back to the 'Living God'.
normative.analysis: Clearly defines what 'ought' to be: a combination of high theology and social action.
quotes: What American Christianity needs more than anything is congregations that combine an unabashed proclamation of the living God...
strengths: Prophetic tone without being abrasive.
Scripturally rooted norms.
improvement_points: The normative 'Living God' concept could be more precisely defined.

pragmatic.servant_leadership: The response is framed as a corporate calling rather than a concrete plan.
pragmatic.analysis: The 'how' is the weakest part of the Osmer framework here.
quotes: Each person may at any time be called out of his or her place to give assistance...
strengths: Validates small, 'homely' acts of service.
improvement_points: Needs more specific 'handles' for the congregation to respond to the 'wilderness' condition.

assimilating_style.analysis: The sermon is highly effective for the assimilating learner. It provides a clear logical framework, historical context (Krummacher), and a systematic critique of American Christianity.
assimilating_style.preferences_addressed: Logical models of church types; theological definitions of 'Theos'.
assimilating_style.risks: It occasionally borders on 'abstract idealism' by spending significant time on the 'state of the church' rather than the text itself.

converging_style.analysis: The converging learner, looking for practical utility, may find the sermon somewhat frustrating. The 'problem' is identified, but the 'solution' is a broad identity shift rather than a specific project.
converging_style.risks: Lapses into generalities like 'telling truth to power'.

accommodating_style.analysis: The accommodating learner is engaged by the opening story and the dramatic description of Elijah, but the middle section is too analytical for this style.
accommodating_style.preferences_addressed: Opening personal anecdote; dramatic 'action figure' imagery.
accommodating_style.risks: The heavy reliance on a 19th-century book may feel 'stale' to an action-oriented learner.

diverging_style.analysis: The diverging learner is well-served by the 'Little Church in the Wilderness' metaphor and the imaginative reconstruction of Elijah and the widow's life together.
diverging_style.preferences_addressed: Metaphors of 'roses among thorns' and 'hidden doves'.
diverging_style.risks: The structure becomes quite rigid in the second half, which may stifle the imaginative flow.

cycle_completeness.analysis: The sermon starts strongly with Concrete Experience (Maryland church) and moves into Reflective Observation (Elijah's ego) and Abstract Conceptualization (The Living God). However, it fails to fully return to a concrete 'Active Experimentation' that is as specific as the opening story.
missing_phases: Active Experimentation is underdeveloped and remains largely theoretical.
cycle_completeness.sequence_and_flow: Maryland Story (CE) -> Elijah's Humility (RO) -> The Living God (AC) -> Church Categories (RO/AC) -> Call to Identity (AE). The flow is logical but the final phase lacks the 'weight' of the first three.

balance_between_phases.analysis: The sermon is heavily weighted toward Reflective Observation and Abstract Conceptualization (the 'top half' of Kolb's cycle).
balance_between_phases.consequences: Hearers may leave with a clearer understanding of their theological situation but without a clear sense of what to do about it.

homiletic_window_movement.analysis: The sermon follows a 'Narrative -> Visionary -> Declarative -> Pragmatic' movement. It starts with a story, moves to the vision of the 'wilderness church,' declares the truth of the Living God, and ends with a call to service.
homiletic_window_movement.identified_structure: Narrative (Maryland/Elijah) -> Visionary (Wilderness Metaphor) -> Declarative (Theological Critique) -> Pragmatic (Call to Service).
homiletic_window_movement.effectiveness: The movement is effective for an intellectual congregation but loses some narrative steam in the 'Declarative' section.

holistic_learning.analysis: The sermon addresses the head (theology) and eyes (observation) very well. The heart (experience) is addressed in the beginning and end. The hands (experimentation) are the least engaged.
holistic_learning.epistemological_approach: Primarily propositional truth (statements about God) mediated through historical narrative.

overall_picture.summary: The sermon is a sophisticated, intellectually stimulating piece that excels in Reflective Observation and Abstract Conceptualization. It provides a clear diagnostic of the contemporary American church through the lens of 1 Kings 17. However, it falls short of a complete Kolb cycle due to a lack of concrete, actionable application. The preacher successfully moves the hearer from a personal anecdote to a broad theological vision, but the 'Active Experimentation' phase remains largely metaphorical. The reliance on Krummacher provides historical depth but occasionally slows the narrative pace. It is a strong 'Declarative' sermon that serves the 'Assimilating' learner well but may leave the 'Converging' learner without a clear path forward.
strengths_top_5: Compelling opening anecdote that establishes the 'wilderness' theme.
Vivid characterization of Elijah as an 'action figure' to engage the imagination.
Sophisticated sociological analysis of the American religious landscape.
Clear and consistent theological focus on the 'Living God'.
Strong use of metaphors (Trojan horse, wadi, hovel) to sustain interest.
improvement_points_top_5: Strengthen Active Experimentation by providing 2-3 specific, non-metaphorical actions for the congregation.
Reduce the length of the 'church categories' section to maintain the narrative tension of the Elijah story.
Integrate the 'widow's son' miracle more deeply into the theological argument rather than treating it as a post-script.
Balance the reliance on Krummacher with more direct, contemporary exegesis of the Hebrew text.
Create a more direct 'bridge' between the 'Living God' concept and the 'social justice' tradition.
excluded_learning_styles: Converging: These hearers will lack the 'how-to' or practical utility they crave.
Accommodating: These hearers may find the long analytical middle section too detached from 'feeling' and 'doing'.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Focus on the 'Pragmatic' quadrant by starting with a problem and ending with a specific 'experiment' for the week.
Try a purely 'Narrative' structure to see if the theological points can emerge from the story itself without the 'Trojan horse' explanation.
Engage the 'Converging' style by asking 'What is one way we will stand before a 'king' this week?'
overall_picture.conclusion: This is a high-quality sermon for a university-town congregation, demonstrating 'priestly listening' and 'prophetic discernment.' From a Kolb perspective, it is a 'top-heavy' sermon that prioritizes reflection and conceptualization over concrete experience and experimentation. While it successfully challenges the 'human-centered' engine of the mainline church, it risks becoming the very thing it critiques—an intellectual exercise—if it does not ground its 'Living God' theology in the 'hands' of the congregation. The priority for improvement is to close the learning cycle by translating the 'vision' of the wilderness church into the 'practice' of the wilderness church.
